trial_identification.studytitle: A phase I study to assess the pharmacokinetics of a single dose of a slow-release solid injection of EPT1647 in healthy male volunteers
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A phase I study to assess the pharmacokinetics of a single dose of a slow-release solid injection of EPT1647 in healthy male volunteers

interventions.interventions: EPT1647 is a derivative of MSH which has been shown to increase eumelanin levels in humans. This study will evaluate the safety and pharmacokinetic profiles of a new formulation of EPT1647 over 30 days.

primaryOutcome.outcome: To determine the pharmacokinetics of a new slow-release solid dose injectable form of EPT1647 administered subcutaneously to healthy men.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured prior to administration of EPT1647, 4, 8 and 12 hours after administration of EPT1647 on day 1, then at days 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, 15 and 30.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To Determine the safety profile of a new slow relase solid dose injectable form of EPT1647 administered subcutaneously to healthy men.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: * Healthy caucasian * No history of Melanoma includinjg in a first degree relative* No significant medical history or disorder* Take precautions to prevent pregnancy during and upto 3 months after study.* No history of drug or alcohol abuse.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To determine how a new implant design of EPT1647 works in the body and to review any side effects that may occur.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Centre for Pharmaceutical Research-University of South Australia

contact.name: Associate Professor Robert Milne
